title: Final Project
text:
I have been a Data Science student for the last three months. Through this class I learned not only to do amazing graphs but also how to ethically analyze the data.
In this website you are going to see a collection of the projects I have done on over the last 3 months. I had a lot of fun learning how to code Rstudio and make different graph and tables to communicate my message. I hope that you enjoy looking at my work as much as I enjoyed making it.
Website is divided into:

My Page: Introduction to the website.
About: Information about the author.
Map: Mapping data piece.
SQL: SQL data piece.
Wrangling: Wrangling data piece.

title: About Me
text:
My name is Shoowee Pieshine. My name was generated from this site. My photo is from here. In this website you are going to see a collection of the projects I have been working on for the last 3 months. I had a lot of fun learning how to code Rstudio and make different graph and tables to communicate my message. I hope that you enjoy looking at my work as much as I enjoyed making it.


If you would like to contact me please do so at 222-444-5555

title: My page
text:
# For your final project you will build a website displaying three pieces that show off:
You do not need to make new versions of these things. You can just move the files into this new project you’ve created. If you have kept organized this should be quick. If you have not kept organized remember that your github repos have your work in them. You are welcome to make new data pieces, but don’t spend to much time on that.

title: My page
section: You will get two outcomes from this project:
text:
You will get two outcomes from this project:

You will learn a bit about how to publish a website on the internet.
You will understand the filing structure that R (and all programming languages) use.

title: My page
text:
Requirements:

All your wrangling, SQL and mapping files must be individual files on different webpages. They must be rendered to html.
For each bit you must reflect on what you learned or why you like a particular piece (200 words max).
Your website will have 5 pages minimum:

Landing page - this will describe the class, what you did, your thoughts on it, and what the website contains, its a summary. You can add a bit about yourself, but no identifying information. Saying Intro to Data Science is okay, but you shouldn’t mention Smith College.
One page per data piece.
An about page so people can contact you to hire you (Add a different photo to the fake contact page). You can not add identifying info here.

You will make use of the nav bar.
Your website should look professional use any of the skills from 192 or 100. Consider headers and links.
Your website must be pushed to github and turned on and working. So please test it. When you are done submit the link to your site to the forum on moodle.

title: My page
text:
Optional:

Here is the website for quarto websites.
Change the theme of your website.
Customize your website using ideas from here.

title: My page
text:
A few things to note:

I am meant to protect your identity as students, so please do not put your personal information on the website. Use the made up contact information for your contact. Don’t even say Smith College. Remember even if you pages are public your repos are private.
After your website is graded, I’ll turn them off. If you would like you can turn them on and do whatever you want with it. Keep in mind when you graduate from Smith you’ll lose your Smith email and likely your repo/website. But you’ll still have them as files on your computer.
This is meant to be a simple skill that students last semester wished they knew how to do. It should not be very very time consuming. Make something that meet requirements then move on. You can perfect it over the summer.

title: In-class Exercises: Mapping
In-class Exercises: Mapping
text:
Exercise
Draw an interactive map of a previous school or place you went.

title: Mapping
section: Interactive map of Macleish station illustrating wetland area

title: SQL
text:
Table of Andie MacDowell’s full filmography, in chronological order


                                                    title production_year
1       Greystoke: The Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Apes            1984
2                                         St. Elmo's Fire            1985
3                                Sex, Lies, and Videotape            1989
4                                              Green Card            1990
5                                             Hudson Hawk            1991
6                                    The Object of Beauty            1991
7                                              Ruby Cairo            1992
8                                              The Player            1992
9  Luck, Trust & Ketchup: Robert Altman in Carver Country            1993
10                                          Groundhog Day            1993
                 name
1    Miss Jane Porter
2       Dale Biberman
3  Ann Bishop Mullany
4             BrontÃ«
5        Anna Baragli
6                Tina
7         Bessie Faro
8     Andie MacDowell
9             Herself
10               Rita


Figure: Table showing Andi MacDowell’s full filmography, in chronological order. It shows the title of the movie, production year, and the name of the character she played. I learned how to wrangle data (in SQL, by joining different tables) through the process of this piece, and it was very fun!

title: Mapping
text:
Interactive map of Magic Kingdom Theme Park






Figure: I created an interactive map of Magic Kingdom Theme park in Orlando, Florida. I did this by using the leaflet package in Rstudio. You can adjust the view and navigate around the area.

title: Wrangling
text:
Table of the stop and frisk program in NYC, wrangled to show the number and percentage of stops per race


# A tibble: 6 × 3
  race_cat                        stops percent_stops
  <chr>                           <int>         <dbl>
1 BLACK                          350743        52.9  
2 WHITE-HISPANIC                 175302        26.4  
3 WHITE                           61805         9.32 
4 BLACK-HISPANIC                  48438         7.30 
5 ASIAN/PACIFIC ISLANDER          23932         3.61 
6 AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKAN NATIVE   2897         0.437


Figure: Table showing the number and percentages of stops by race from the NYC stop and frisk program. I did this table by mutating, summarizing, and organizing my data in a way that I could use the result to show the total number of stops for each race and the percentages associated with it.
